text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES

Minor editorial changes have been made throughout this IRM. Legal citations, form and letter references, and IRM references were reviewed and updated as necessary. Other signiﬁcant changes include the following:

Reference Description of Change IRM 4.8.5.1 Included section to outline internal controls. IRM 4.8.5.2.2.1.2(2) Clariﬁed procedures for when a ﬁnal determina- and (3) tion letter should be issued. IRM Provided instructions for updating ISTS. 4.8.5.2.2.2(7)(d) IRM Provided instructions for 90 Day suspense 4.8.5.2.2.2.1(1)(d) clerk. IRM Provided instructions for 90 Day suspense 4.8.5.2.2.2.2(1)(d) clerk. IRM 4.8.5.4 Clariﬁed the procedures for TEFRA / non- TEFRA cases being returned from Appeals to Examination ﬁeld groups and Campus groups. Exhibit 4.8.5-1 Converted exhibit to XML software vs. a graphic ﬁle. Exhibit 4.8.5-2 Converted exhibit to XML software vs. a graphic ﬁle.
Small Business Self-Employed (SB/SE), Technical Services Employees, Centralized Case Processing, and Large Business and International (LB&I) employees.
Table of Contents
Cases Returned From Appeals for a Statutory Notice of Deﬁciency
Case Processing Requirements

) Purpose. This IRM section describes the procedures for the review of that have special features requiring post examination processing and The following types of cases require post examination processing a. Innocent Spouse b. TEFRA cases c. Cases returned from Appeals d. Refer to IRM
, Fraud Program Responsibilities, for all suspense processing procedures related to fraud and grand jury cases. e. Refer to IRM
, Bankruptcy Suspense, for all suspense and cessing procedures related to bankruptcy cases. (
) Audience. These procedures apply to Technical Services employees to the various programs discussed in this IRM. (
) Policy Owner. The Technical Services office is under Examination Field Examination. (

) Program Owner. Technical Services is the program office responsible for cessing and closing cases which include the following (but not limited to): a. Innocent Spouse cases b. TEFRA Case Reviews c. Cases returned from Appeals (
) Contact Information. To recommend changes or make any other this IRM section, e-mail the author. (
) The Technical Services area was established in

when the various business units such as SB/SE, LB&I, and W&I were realigned and their re- spective Examination and Collection areas were aligned separately. As Technical Services serves as the overall closing function for Field cases and speciﬁcally for the various situations as listed in IRM
) By law, the Service has the authority to make the appropriate assessments once the examination is completed and the taxpayer has been notiﬁed of the audit results. IRM
details the procedures to be followed when cases contain an Innocent Spouse claim as provided for by IRC TEFRA features, or is being returned to Technical Services by Appeals. (

) The Director, Examination - Technical Services is the executive responsible the inventory control and case processing in Technical Services. The responsibilities are as outlined below in this IRM. (
) Audience - The employees responsible for taking action or who require knowledge about the program, process or activity. (
) Pre Assessment - when a claim is received prior to the assessment of the proposed deﬁciency. (
) Post Assessment - when a claim is received by the examiner for of a tax liability that has already been assessed. (
) Jurisdiction released - when Appeals releases their jurisdiction over the and returns the case to Examination for further actions to be taken.

Purpose. This IRM section describes the procedures for the review of cases that have special features requiring post examination processing procedures. The following types of cases require post examination processing procedures:
b. TEFRA cases c. Cases returned from Appeals d. Refer to IRM
, Fraud Program Responsibilities, for all suspense and processing procedures related to fraud and grand jury cases. e. Refer to IRM
, Bankruptcy Suspense, for all suspense and pro- cessing procedures related to bankruptcy cases.
Program Owner. Technical Services is the program office responsible for pro- cessing and closing cases which include the following (but not limited to):
Jurisdiction released - when Appeals releases their jurisdiction over the case and returns the case to Examination for further actions to be taken.
The table lists commonly used acronyms and their deﬁnitions:

Acronym Deﬁnition AD Area director AIMS Audit Information Management System ASED Assessment statute expiration date AUSA Assistant United States Attorney BOD Business operating division CCP Centralized Case Processing CCISO Cincinnati Centralized Innocent Spouse Operations ERCS Examination Returns Control System FPAA Final Partnership Administrative Adjustment GM Group manager IDRS Integrated Data Retrieval System IS Innocent Spouse ISTS Innocent Spouse Tracking System NRS Non-requesting Spouse PCS Partnership Control System PSP Planning and Special Programs RAR Revenue Agent Report RGS Report Generation Software RS Requesting Spouse SNOD Statutory notice of deﬁciency TAS Taxpayer Advocate Services TEFRA Tax Equity Fiscal Responsibility Act TM Territory manager TS Technical Services
IRM

, Relief From Joint and Several Liability, contains detailed guidance for examining and processing innocent spouse cases. This section will address the review of innocent spouse cases worked in the area offices. Cases worked in Cincinnati Centralized Innocent Spouse Operations (CCISO) will be reviewed using IRM
, Quality Assurance.
Examination Case Processing Requirements 4.8.5

) All requests for relief from joint and several liability or “innocent spouse” are subject to innocent spouse review and processing procedures as in this section. a. Pre-Assessment Claims: Cases worked by examiners involving a claim ﬁled during the course of an examination are pre-assessment claims. claim becomes part of the examination and Technical Services receives the case after a determination is made and the taxpayers are notiﬁed, whether the case is agreed or unagreed. See IRM

, Field tion Procedures. b. Post-Assessment Claims: Cases worked by examiners involving a for consideration of a tax liability that has already been assessed. Post- assessment claims will be forwarded to Technical Services after a determination is made but before any determination letters/notices are issued. (

) The reviewer will ensure consistency of determinations made by examiners based on the facts, circumstances, and law of each case. This requires keeping current on innocent spouse tax law and procedures. The reviewer’s duties include, but are not limited to the following: a. Coordinate and conduct reviews of the incoming cases. Incoming cases will be worked in the order listed in IRM

). b. Support area examiners, managers, revenue officers, Appeals, Counsel and other area employees with the development and processing of innocent spouse claim cases as needed. c. Assist Centralized Case Processing (CCP) as needed. This includes resolving problems that arise after processing of the case is complete (e.g., offsetting an overpayment after a claim was ﬁled, etc.). d. Review cases that default from
Day suspense after innocent spouse preliminary determination letters are issued. See the list of items to in IRM

). e. Assist other reviewers when necessary. f. Inform Collection and TAS of determinations made on cases in their nization by contacting them and sending them copies of any requested documentation. The lien clerk will be given copies of the letters if liens exist and partial / full relief was determined. g. Maintain and update existing innocent spouse review procedures. (

) Innocent spouse cases will be worked in the following order: a. TAS cases marked expedite b. Open docketed cases c. TAS cases not marked expedite d. Open examination cases e. Date received in Technical Services (

) Prior to closure of the innocent spouse claim cases, the reviewer must the following: a. They contain all required documentation. b. They are assembled properly. c. All ﬁnal determination letters are signed and ready to be issued. d. The case processing closing instruction documents are complete and accurate. e. Innocent Spouse Tracking System (ISTS) is updated correctly. Internal Revenue Manual
All requests for relief from joint and several liability or “innocent spouse” cases are subject to innocent spouse review and processing procedures as outlined in this section.

Pre-Assessment Claims: Cases worked by examiners involving a claim ﬁled during the course of an examination are pre-assessment claims. The claim becomes part of the examination and Technical Services receives the case after a determination is made and the taxpayers are notiﬁed, whether the case is agreed or unagreed. See IRM

, Field tion Procedures. Post-Assessment Claims: Cases worked by examiners involving a claim for consideration of a tax liability that has already been assessed. Post- assessment claims will be forwarded to Technical Services after a determination is made but before any determination letters/notices are issued.

They contain all required documentation. They are assembled properly. All ﬁnal determination letters are signed and ready to be issued. The case processing closing instruction documents are complete and accurate. Innocent Spouse Tracking System (ISTS) is updated correctly.
f. Form
, Special Handling Notice for Examination Case Processing, properly ﬂagged. (
) Pre-assessment cases and post-assessment cases require different procedures for both the examination group and Technical Services staff. IRM

, Field Examination Procedures, for procedures for the tion group. The reviewer must take the following actions: a. Determine whether the claim is pre-assessment or post-assessment. b. Determine whether the claim applies to an underpayment of tax (tax with ﬁled return), understatement (deﬁciency), or both. c. Conﬁrm each claim is on ISTS and updated to the appropriate stages. d. Conﬁrm transaction code (TC)
and action code (AC)
is on claim year (L- freeze is present). Note: If the requesting spouse (RS) is the secondary spouse, the TC AC
will cross reference the secondary spouse’s social number (SSN) (e.g., TC
AC
XREF: XXX-XX-XXXX). If RS is the primary spouse, the TC
AC
will appear a cross reference SSN. Information on each tax year should be veriﬁed to be correct. e. Correct the ISTS record and / or TC, if necessary. (

) The following integrated data retrieval system (IDRS) information will be reviewed and included in the case ﬁle: a. AMDISA - all years b. SPARQ and / or INOLES - for veriﬁcation of current address of both spouses c. IMFOLI - for each spouse to review ﬁling history, balances due, open controls and to look for existing master ﬁle tax (MFT)
accounts d. IMFOLT - for all open exam and claim years, including any MFT

accounts for the same years; and for prior / subsequent years, as for refund - offset payments e. ISTSRA - for all periods f. ISTSRS - for summary showing all claims outstanding for all years, by both primary and secondary taxpayers g. CFINK - checking for taxpayer representatives for each spouse. Note: This list may not be all inclusive. (
) When a claim is received prior to the assessment of the proposed the claim is a “pre-assessment claim.” This usually occurs when an

reviewed and included in the case ﬁle: a. AMDISA - all years b. SPARQ and / or INOLES - for veriﬁcation of current address of both spouses c. IMFOLI - for each spouse to review ﬁling history, balances due, open controls and to look for existing master ﬁle tax (MFT)
accounts d. IMFOLT - for all open exam and claim years, including any MFT

accounts for the same years; and for prior / subsequent years, as for refund - offset payments e. ISTSRA - for all periods f. ISTSRS - for summary showing all claims outstanding for all years, ﬁled by both primary and secondary taxpayers g. CFINK - checking for taxpayer representatives for each spouse.
Note: This list may not be all inclusive.

When a claim is received prior to the assessment of the proposed deﬁciency, the claim is a “pre-assessment claim.” This usually occurs when an examiner receives a claim from the RS during the course of an open examination. If the claim is received directly from the taxpayer (RS), the examiner is responsible for faxing the qualiﬁed (i.e., processable or complete) Form
to the area PSP IS Coordinator and ensuring the TC
AC

(a cross reference SSN is required when the RS is the secondary spouse) is present for each year affected. The innocent spouse reviewer is responsible for ensuring the case is on ISTS and that the proper TC
is present on each year. The spouse claim then becomes another examination issue and is added to the Form
, Examination Workpapers Index, or Form
OA, Examination Workpapers Index - Office Audit, as applicable.

) The examiner contacts the RS via Letter

, Non-requesting Spouse, and gathers information and facts via and / or interviews of both spouses. (
) The examiner determines whether or not relief will be granted, in full / in denied, and under the appropriate code sections. (

) If only one or neither taxpayer responds to requests for additional the examiner must make a determination based on all available information the case ﬁle. Once a determination is made, the examiner issues a revenue agent report (RAR) that includes the innocent spouse claim determination in the “Other Information” section. See IRM

Day letter (i.e., Letter

Day Letter - Straight Deﬁciency) so that both taxpayers are afforded their appeal rights. ) Final processing of post-assessment claims is the responsibility of the area Technical Services innocent spouse reviewer(s) and staff. A claim is one that is received by the examiner for consideration of a tax that has already been assessed. The assessment can be on a return ﬁled tax due, an examination assessment, or both, and it may appear on either MFT
or MFT
of either or both spouses. MFT
most often occurs an innocent spouse request, offer in compromise (OIC), bankruptcy, or fraud criminal restitution assessment is involved. An MFT
can also occur when only one spouse agrees to proposed adjustment, requests appeals, or Tax Court. (
) The case is normally set up on AIMS and ISTS prior to being assigned to an examiner. The examiner contacts the NRS via Letter
and the RS via Letter
which allows
days from the date of the letter for the to respond. (
) The examiner makes a determination on the claim. The determination is written up on the innocent spouse lead sheet or Form
-A, Explanation of Items, and the case is closed to Technical Services for mandatory review issuance of determination letters. (
) Technical Services is responsible for ISTS updates while the case is in Technical Services. Upon receipt of the claim in Technical Services, ISTS be updated to Stage
TOREVU. (

) The claim case will be assigned to an innocent spouse reviewer for review processing procedures. If the case is a referral from Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS), Collection, or a case returned from the ﬁeld after rework, it is treated as a priority case.

Final processing of post-assessment claims is the responsibility of the area Technical Services innocent spouse reviewer(s) and staff. A post-assessment claim is one that is received by the examiner for consideration of a tax liability that has already been assessed. The assessment can be on a return ﬁled with tax due, an examination assessment, or both, and it may appear on either the MFT
or MFT
of either or both spouses. MFT
most often occurs when an innocent spouse request, offer in compromise (OIC), bankruptcy, or fraud criminal restitution assessment is involved. An MFT
can also occur when only one spouse agrees to proposed adjustment, requests appeals, or petitions Tax Court.

Final processing of post-assessment claims is the responsibility of the area Technical Services innocent spouse reviewer(s) and staff. A post-assessment claim is one that is received by the examiner for consideration of a tax liability that has already been assessed. The assessment can be on a return ﬁled with tax due, an examination assessment, or both, and it may appear on either the MFT 30 or MFT 31 of either or both spouses. MFT 31 most often occurs when an innocent spouse request, offer in compromise (OIC), bankruptcy, or fraud criminal restitution assessment is involved. An MFT 31 can also occur when only one spouse agrees to proposed adjustment, requests appeals, or Tax Court.

) Collection: If the case is a Collection referral, complete Form

, Referral Report, Part B. Place a copy in the case ﬁle and return the original Form to the revenue officer with a copy of the determination letter(s). If there is a lien and the requesting spouse is granted FULL RELIEF, provide a copy of determination letter to the lien release unit and request a partial lien release with regard to the requesting spouse ONLY. Provide the lien release unit with all SSNs and the years to which the partial tax lien release applies. (

) Taxpayer Advocate: If the case is a Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) case, call the advocate handling the case to advise the case is being closed. Generally, TAS will request copies of documents from the ﬁle for their case (e.g., the determination letter, Appeals request, etc.). Do not close a TAS without contacting the advocate ﬁrst. (
) Returning Cases to Examiners: The most common error that causes a case be returned to an examiner is failure to issue the

day letter to the taxpayer(s) with the RAR indicating the innocent spouse determination (pre- assessment case) when sufficient time remains on the statute of limitations. such a situation, return the case on a Form
, Reviewer’s Report, and the examiner to the procedures in IRM
(h), Examiner’s Responsibili- ties, and IRM
, Report Writing. Update ISTS Stage
with the appropriate activity. Refer to IRM
, Stage
— Local Review, and IRM
, Stage
— Rework. (

) Claim Filed After a Statutory Notice of Deﬁciency Issued: In general, if an innocent spouse claim is ﬁled after the issuance of a statutory notice of deﬁ- ciency on a joint account, the claim needs to be screened to determine whether or not it is processable (i.e., all required information provided, signature present, etc.). a. If the claim is valid, it will be set up on ISTS and TC
AC

will be input on the account. This is accomplished by contacting the innocent spouse coordinator or an innocent spouse reviewer. Once the statutory notice of deﬁciency defaults, the deﬁciency (plus related penalties) will be assessed on the MFT
joint account using partial assessment proce- dures and the case will be returned to the group on a Form
(in Status Code

) for consideration of the innocent spouse claim. This procedure reduces taxpayer burden by getting the claim worked as as possible. It also allows the examiner to work the claim using the original administrative ﬁle without reopening the case. b. If a petition is ﬁled in response to the statutory notice of deﬁciency, the consideration of the innocent spouse claim must be coordinated with counsel. (
) MFT
Assessments Present: the guidance in this IRM section is premised the fact that joint liabilities will be present on MFT
joint accounts. There circumstances in which liabilities originating from joint returns may be present on MFT
accounts for one or both spouses. In those cases, special instruc- tions are sometimes required to adjust the MFT
accounts for the amount relief allowed. If in doubt, contact the applicable innocent spouse reviewer or the CCP-FORT for assistance.

MFT
Assessments Present: the guidance in this IRM section is premised on the fact that joint liabilities will be present on MFT
joint accounts. There are circumstances in which liabilities originating from joint returns may be present on MFT
accounts for one or both spouses. In those cases, special instruc- tions are sometimes required to adjust the MFT
accounts for the amount of relief allowed. If in doubt, contact the applicable innocent spouse reviewer or the CCP-FORT for assistance.

Note: TEFRA cases returned from Appeals to the Exam ﬁeld groups should be returned to the original TS TEFRA coordinator who reviewed the case before
TEFRA / non-TEFRA cases returned to the Campus from Appeals to complete other actions will be updated on AIMS to Status Code
(Campus). The Campus TEFRA / non-TEFRA functions will update the to Status Code
(TEFRA) /

(non-TEFRA) upon receipt of the database. There are two methods Appeals can use to return cases to the area. One method is referred to as “jurisdiction released” and the other method is to as “jurisdiction not released.” a. A “jurisdiction released” case is routed from Appeals to Technical Services via Form
, Appeals Division Feedback Report and Transmittal Memorandum. A minimum of
days must be remaining on the statute of limitations when received by Technical Services. Technical Services assumes responsibility for jurisdiction released cases, including the re-
A “jurisdiction released” case is routed from Appeals to Technical Services via Form
, Appeals Division Feedback Report and Transmittal Memorandum. A minimum of
days must be remaining on the statute of limitations when received by Technical Services. Technical Services assumes responsibility for jurisdiction released cases, including the re-

sponsibility for statute management. Reviewers are responsible for identiﬁcation and protection of statutes of limitation on all returns assigned to them or for which they have control. Procedures for statute controls are located in IRM 25.6.23, Examination Process—Assessment Statute of Limitations Controls. Procedures for consents are located in IRM 25.6.22, Extension of Assessment Statute of Limitations by Consent.
Extension of Assessment Statute of Limitations by Consent. Caution: Occasionally, Appeals will route the case to Technical Services without updating AIMS to Status Code
or will route the case directly to the examination group without updating the case to Status Code

When this occurs, the AIMS/ERCS staff will be contacted to correct the status code. b. A “jurisdiction not released” case occurs when Appeals retains ity for a case, including the responsibility for statute management. The AIMS controls for the case remain with Appeals. Only the case ﬁle is returned to the ﬁeld examiner. Once the ﬁeld examiner completes his or her actions, the case ﬁle will be returned directly to Appeals by the ﬁeld examiner. Unagreed cases designated for closure to Appeals and cases requiring completion of post-examination processing require priority handling, as refer- enced in IRM

, Cases Requiring Priority Handling. If the reviewer does not agree with the appeals officer’s recommendations and the Technical Services group manager concurs, a responding or clarifying memorandum is prepared and returned to Appeals with the case ﬁle. If the reviewer agrees with the appeals officer’s recommendations and the Technical Services group manager concurs, the case is returned to the exami- nation group for completion of the required actions. If the case returns to Appeals after the required actions are completed, the statute of limitations must have at least
days remaining when the case is received in Appeals.

Services in the following situations: a. If the matter is factual. b. If the case requires further development or veriﬁcation of new information. c. If it’s more efficient and/or expedient for the original examiner to complete the work. (
) Cases should not be returned to the group if the matter is one of legal tation and is not a matter of factual development.
a. If the matter is factual. b. If the case requires further development or veriﬁcation of new information. c. If it’s more efficient and/or expedient for the original examiner to complete the work.
Cases should not be returned to the group if the matter is one of legal interpre- tation and is not a matter of factual development.

In addition to applying the applicable IRM program procedures, reviewers will also consider the case return criteria. See IRM 4.8.2.9.1, Case Return Criteria. This is to determine whether a quality examina- tion has been performed and if Technical Services has determined additional examination action is necessary, which may not have been
Examination Case Processing Requirements 4.8.5 page

addressed by Appeals. If the reviewer identiﬁes additional errors, problems, or shortcomings with the case not identiﬁed by the officer on Form 10467, the reviewer should prepare Form 3990, Form 886-A, if needed, to accompany the case when returned to group.

) Because Appeals released jurisdiction of the case, AIMS is updated and the case is returned to the ﬁeld. Upon completion of the additional ﬁeld work, the group closes the case either by using normal procedures without additional action by Technical Services or by returning it to Technical Services for pro- cessing as appropriate. (
) If Appeals did not release jurisdiction, the case is returned to the ﬁeld. Upon completion of the required ﬁeld work, the case closes from the ﬁeld to Appeals. (

) For unsettled listed transaction cases, Appeals will return the case to Technical Services for the preparation and issuance of a statutory notice of deﬁciency when an agreement is not secured. In these situations, Appeals will provide the notice language (e.g.,
Project Cases).

cessing as appropriate.
